questions.stem: Equine metabolic syndrome (EMS) is best described as:

options.label: A
options.text: A congenital musculoskeletal deformity that causes acute laminitis in foals

options.label: B
options.text: A collection of clinical and clinicopathologic changes that increase risk of hyperinsulinemia‑associated laminitis in equids

options.label: C
options.text: A primary pituitary disorder that causes pars intermedia hyperplasia and laminitis

options.label: D
options.text: An infectious metabolic disease caused by a high‑sugar diet in adult horses

questions.explanation: EMS is a characteristic collection of clinical signs and clinicopathologic changes in equids that increases the risk of hyperinsulinemia‑associated laminitis (HAL). It is not a congenital deformity (A), primary pituitary disease (C), or an infectious process (D).

questions.stem: The core pathophysiologic abnormality in equine metabolic syndrome is:

options.label: A
options.text: Hyperlipemia

options.label: B
options.text: Insulin dysregulation

options.label: C
options.text: Primary hypothyroidism

options.label: D
options.text: Hyponatremia

questions.explanation: Insulin dysregulation (ID) is the core component of EMS, leading to hyperinsulinemia and laminitis risk. Hyperlipemia (A) can occur with severe feed restriction, while primary hypothyroidism (C) and hyponatremia (D) are not central to EMS.

questions.stem: Which group is MOST commonly affected by EMS?

options.label: A
options.text: Ponies and certain easy‑keeper horse breeds such as Morgans and Paso Finos

options.label: B
options.text: Young Thoroughbred racehorses

options.label: C
options.text: Neonatal foals of any breed

options.label: D
options.text: Geriatric Standardbreds only

questions.explanation: EMS is most common in ponies and certain “easy‑keeper” breeds such as Saddlebreds, Tennessee Walking Horses, Paso Finos, Morgans, and Mustangs. Thoroughbreds and Standardbreds (B, D) are less frequently affected, and foals (C) are not the typical population.

questions.stem: A typical body condition profile of a horse with EMS includes:

options.label: A
options.text: Emaciation with prominent ribs and no regional adiposity

options.label: B
options.text: Normal body condition with no fat accumulation

options.label: C
options.text: Obesity or overconditioning with regional adiposity at the neck and tailhead

options.label: D
options.text: Cachexia with muscle wasting and potbelly

questions.explanation: Affected horses are often obese or overconditioned with regional adiposity, especially a cresty neck and fat at the tailhead. Emaciation (A) and cachexia (D) are the opposite of EMS, and normal body condition (B) does not reflect the typical phenotype.

questions.stem: Which statement regarding the relationship between EMS and PPID is MOST accurate?

options.label: A
options.text: EMS and PPID never occur together

options.label: B
options.text: PPID is the only cause of laminitis in older horses, not EMS

options.label: C
options.text: EMS and PPID can occur concurrently in middle‑aged and older horses, and each horse should be evaluated for both

options.label: D
options.text: Horses with PPID should not be tested for insulin dysregulation

questions.explanation: EMS and PPID can occur concurrently in middle‑aged and older horses, and horses with one condition should be evaluated for the other. They clearly can coexist (contradicting A), PPID is not the only cause of laminitis (B), and PPID horses should indeed be checked for ID (D).

questions.stem: What is the main mechanism by which EMS predisposes horses to laminitis?

options.label: A
options.text: Bacterial toxin absorption from the gut

options.label: B
options.text: Direct damage to the digital cushion by obesity

options.label: C
options.text: Hyperinsulinemia leading to laminar pathology

options.label: D
options.text: Vitamin E deficiency causing oxidative damage in the hoof

questions.explanation: Hyperinsulinemia is the key mediator linking EMS to laminitis, with high insulin concentrations damaging laminar tissues. Bacterial toxins (A), direct fat compression of the hoof (B), and vitamin E deficiency (D) are not the primary mechanisms in EMS‑associated laminitis.

questions.stem: Which clinical finding is MOST consistent with EMS?

options.label: A
options.text: Underweight horse with low body condition score and no hoof changes

options.label: B
options.text: Overconditioned horse with a cresty neck and fat deposits at the tailhead

options.label: C
options.text: Young foal with angular limb deformity

options.label: D
options.text: Adult horse with acute fever and neutropenia

questions.explanation: A classic EMS horse is overconditioned or obese with a cresty neck and regional fat deposits. Underweight horses (A) and cachectic horses (D) do not match this picture, and there is often a history or risk of laminitis rather than an entirely normal horse (B).

questions.stem: In a horse with EMS, subtle evidence of prior laminitis may include:

options.label: A
options.text: Petechial hemorrhages on mucous membranes

options.label: B
options.text: Hoof growth rings and radiographic evidence of third phalanx rotation

options.label: C
options.text: Swelling of digital flexor tendons without hoof change

options.label: D
options.text: Sole bruising only

questions.explanation: Abnormal hoof growth rings and radiographic evidence of third phalanx rotation or pedal osteitis are typical occult signs of prior laminitis in EMS. Petechiae (A), tendon swelling (C), and sole bruising alone (D) are not characteristic evidence of past laminitis episodes in EMS.

questions.stem: The primary goal of diagnostic testing for EMS is to:

options.label: A
options.text: Confirm hypothyroidism as the underlying cause of obesity

options.label: B
options.text: Document insulin dysregulation through appropriate testing

options.label: C
options.text: Identify pituitary tumors via MRI

options.label: D
options.text: Detect bacterial pathogens in blood culture

questions.explanation: The main diagnostic objective is to document insulin dysregulation using appropriate endocrine tests (e.g., resting insulin, OST, OGT). Hypothyroidism (A) and pituitary imaging (C) are not primary goals, and bacteremia (D) is irrelevant in EMS.

questions.stem: Why is it important to perform EMS diagnostic testing in a controlled, low‑stress environment?

options.label: A
options.text: Stress and diet can alter blood glucose and insulin concentrations, affecting test interpretation

options.label: B
options.text: Stress decreases the risk of laminitis and masks EMS

options.label: C
options.text: Stress has no impact on endocrine testing results

options.label: D
options.text: Stress only affects liver enzymes, not insulin

questions.explanation: Diet, pain, and stress significantly influence blood glucose and insulin concentrations, so testing must be done under controlled, low‑stress conditions for valid results. Stress does not mask EMS (B), and it clearly does affect endocrine tests (C, D).

questions.stem: During an oral sugar test (OST) in a horse suspected of EMS, which result supports a diagnosis of insulin dysregulation?

options.label: A
options.text: Insulin concentration of 20 mIU/mL at 60–90 minutes

options.label: B
options.text: Insulin concentration of 45 mIU/mL or greater at 60–90 minutes

options.label: C
options.text: Insulin concentration of 10 mIU/mL at 2 hours

options.label: D
options.text: Insulin concentration that decreases after corn syrup administration

questions.explanation: In the OST, an insulin concentration ≥ 45 mIU/mL at 60–90 minutes after corn syrup administration is consistent with insulin dysregulation. Lower values (A, C, D) would not meet the described diagnostic threshold.

questions.stem: A fasted horse undergoes an oral glucose test (OGT). Which finding is consistent with insulin dysregulation?

options.label: A
options.text: Insulin ≥ 65 mIU/mL 2 hours after 0.75 g/kg dextrose

options.label: B
options.text: Insulin ≤ 20 mIU/mL 2 hours after dextrose

options.label: C
options.text: Insulin unchanged from baseline at 24 hours

options.label: D
options.text: Insulin < 10 mIU/mL 30 minutes after dextrose

questions.explanation: In the OGT, an insulin concentration ≥ 65 mIU/mL 2 hours after giving 0.75 g/kg dextrose mixed with chaff is consistent with ID. The other answer choices describe lower or non‑diagnostic responses (B–D).

questions.stem: Which resting insulin concentration indicates an ACCEPTABLE response to current management and LOW risk of laminitis in a horse with EMS?

options.label: A
options.text: ≤ 50 mIU/mL

options.label: B
options.text: Between 50 and 100 mIU/mL

options.label: C
options.text: ≥ 100 mIU/mL

options.label: D
options.text: ≥ 200 mIU/mL

questions.explanation: A blood insulin concentration ≤ 50 mIU/mL indicates an acceptable response to management and a low risk of laminitis. Values between 50–100 mIU/mL (B) are equivocal, and ≥ 100 mIU/mL (C, D) indicate poor control and high risk.

questions.stem: Which resting insulin concentration suggests inadequate management and HIGH risk of laminitis?

options.label: A
options.text: ≤ 20 mIU/mL

options.label: B
options.text: 30–40 mIU/mL

options.label: C
options.text: ≥ 100 mIU/mL

options.label: D
options.text: Exactly 50 mIU/mL

questions.explanation: A blood insulin concentration ≥ 100 mIU/mL signifies inadequate management and a high laminitis risk. Lower or borderline values (A, B, D) do not indicate the same level of concern.

questions.stem: Which dietary recommendation is MOST appropriate for managing a horse with EMS?

options.label: A
options.text: Free‑choice pasture and grain to maintain weight

options.label: B
options.text: Eliminating grazing, grains, and treats; feeding low‑NSC hay divided into several small meals

options.label: C
options.text: Feeding high‑NSC hay once daily to reduce boredom

options.label: D
options.text: Unlimited carrots and apples as low‑calorie treats

questions.explanation: Management focuses on eliminating grazing, grains, and treats and feeding low‑NSC hay divided into multiple small meals. Free‑choice pasture and grain (A) and high‑NSC feeding strategies (C, D) directly oppose recommended practice and increase laminitis risk.

questions.stem: When feeding hay to an OBESE horse with EMS, which guideline is MOST appropriate initially?

options.label: A
options.text: 0.5% of body weight per day of any available hay

options.label: B
options.text: 1.5% of body weight per day of low‑NSC hay, avoiding severe restriction that could trigger hyperlipemia

options.label: C
options.text: 4% of body weight per day of high‑NSC hay

options.label: D
options.text: Only pasture, no hay, to encourage movement

questions.explanation: For obese EMS horses, feeding low‑NSC hay at about 1.5% of body weight per day is recommended, avoiding overly severe restriction to reduce hyperlipemia risk. Extreme restriction (A), very high intake (C), or pasture‑only (D) are inappropriate.

questions.stem: In horses with EMS, how should nonstructural carbohydrate (NSC) intake per meal be managed?

options.label: A
options.text: There is no need to limit NSC per meal

options.label: B
options.text: NSC should not exceed 0.1 g/kg per meal

options.label: C
options.text: NSC should be at least 1 g/kg per meal

options.label: D
options.text: NSC should be restricted only in the evening

questions.explanation: Nonstructural carbohydrate intake should not exceed about 0.1 g/kg per meal to limit glycemic and insulinemic spikes. The other options either ignore restriction (A), recommend excessive NSC (C), or arbitrarily time restriction (D).

questions.stem: Which management strategy best describes appropriate hoof care for horses with EMS?

options.label: A
options.text: Hoof care is not necessary unless acute lameness is present

options.label: B
options.text: Radiographs are never indicated in EMS cases

options.label: C
options.text: Regular hoof trimming every 4 weeks by a skilled farrier and radiographic monitoring for laminitis

options.label: D
options.text: Only corrective shoeing is required once laminitis is severe

questions.explanation: Regular hoof trimming every 4 weeks by an experienced farrier, along with radiographic monitoring, is recommended because HAL can occur without obvious lameness. Neglecting hoof care (A, B) or waiting for severe laminitis before intervening (D) is unsafe.

questions.stem: After laminitis has resolved in a horse with EMS, which statement about exercise is MOST accurate?

options.label: A
options.text: Exercise should be permanently avoided

options.label: B
options.text: Only light hand‑walking once monthly is beneficial

options.label: C
options.text: Gradual, structured exercise improves insulin sensitivity by building muscle and reducing fat mass

options.label: D
options.text: Exercise has no effect on insulin regulation

questions.explanation: After laminitis resolution, appropriate exercise helps improve insulin sensitivity by building muscle and reducing fat mass, and is an important part of EMS management. Permanent rest (A), minimal activity (B), or ignoring the metabolic benefits of exercise (D) are not supported.

questions.stem: Which statement best summarizes prevention of EMS in at‑risk horses?

options.label: A
options.text: Provide high‑NSC diets year‑round but limit exercise

options.label: B
options.text: Feed according to generic guidelines, regardless of body condition

options.label: C
options.text: Provide an appropriate diet, maintain normal body condition, and restrict grazing during times of high soluble carbohydrates

options.label: D
options.text: Allow unrestricted pasture access in spring and autumn to promote natural weight changes

questions.explanation: Prevention emphasizes an appropriate, individualized diet, maintaining normal body condition, and strict grazing restriction during times of high soluble carbohydrate (spring and autumn), especially in high‑risk breeds. High‑NSC diets (A), generic feeding without regard to condition (B), and unrestricted pasture during risky seasons (D) all increase EMS and laminitis risk.
